image.altText: Recruitment difficulty not cause of Qantas' staffing crisis, CEO says

items.synopsis: Local shares make gains, but Fortescue shares drop. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce fronts a parliamentary committee on cost of living. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Qantas boss faces Senate over soaring airfares and profits, ASX rises, Fortescue shares down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas says it's holding around $100 million in credits belonging to Jetstar customers. Previously, the airline said it was holding $370 million in credits for Australian customers. But under questioning from senators in Melbourne, it said that doesn't include Jetstar or international customers. Executive Steph Tully says around 50 per cent of the credit is held by people with less than $100 in credit remaining.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas holding $100 million in Jetstar customer credits

children.content: Qantas says it's holding around $100 million in credits belonging to Jetstar customers.

Previously, the airline said it was holding $370 million in credits for Australian customers. But under questioning from senators in Melbourne, it said that doesn't include Jetstar or international customers.
Executive Steph Tully says around 50 per cent of the credit is held by people with less than $100 in credit remaining.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has been questioned about the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from operating additional flights. Competitor airline Virgin Australia has slammed the government's call in recent days, with boss Jayne Hrdlicka criticising the move in a video released to staff. Today, the Australian Financial Review published comments from Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones, explaining why the government decision to block the extra Qatar flights was in the national interest. “We can drive prices down but if we drive them down to a level where it's actually unsustainable to run an airline, instead of having two carriers we will design our markets in a way which will make it unsustainable for the existing Australian-based carrier," Mr Jones told the AFR in response to their questions. Asked about Mr Jones's comment this afternoon, Mr Joyce said granting traffic rights was a bilateral exercise. "Various countries around the world protect the national interest and I think what the [assistant] treasurer was referring to is Australians should protect its own national interest, and that is making sure we get reciprocal or other arrangements when you grant traffic rights. "I don't think anyone would say you should grant traffic rights that would mean that you are disadvantaged in the Australian national interest and I think the assistant treasurer was saying that in our mind and we would agree with that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Joyce backs denying extra Qatar Airways flights in 'national interest'

children.content: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has been questioned about the federal government's decision to block Qatar Airways from operating additional flights.
Competitor airline Virgin Australia has slammed the government's call in recent days, with boss Jayne Hrdlicka criticising the move in a video released to staff.
Today,
the Australian Financial Review published comments from Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones
, explaining why the government decision to block the extra Qatar flights was in the national interest.

“We can drive prices down but if we drive them down to a level where it's actually unsustainable to run an airline, instead of having two carriers we will design our markets in a way which will make it unsustainable for the existing Australian-based carrier," Mr Jones told the AFR in response to their questions.
Asked about Mr Jones's comment this afternoon, Mr Joyce said granting traffic rights was a bilateral exercise.

"Various countries around the world protect the national interest and I think what the [assistant] treasurer was referring to is Australians should protect its own national interest, and that is making sure we get reciprocal or other arrangements when you grant traffic rights.

"I don't think anyone would say you should grant traffic rights that would mean that you are disadvantaged in the Australian national interest and I think the assistant treasurer was saying that in our mind and we would agree with that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The head of Qantas says he "understands" criticism of the airline's large profit, at a time many are struggling with the cost of living. Fronting a Senate inquiry, Alan Joyce has used his opening statement to argue that airlines are facing "a raft of escalating costs". "When borders finally opened, the return to flying was not nearly as smooth as we had hoped," he said of the post-COVID chaos facing many travellers. "Sick leave, supply chain issues and aircraft still in hibernation meant the industry could not meet the huge demand for travel. "The result was long queues, delays and cancellations, particularly in domestic services, and for our part we apologise sincerely." Mr Joyce also said airfares had peaked and were now trending down. "To fix it quickly we had to cut capacity to reduce pressure on the system. This created an imbalance between supply and demand, which meant fares rose across all airlines. "At the same time, fuel prices spiked by more than 60 per cent compared to pre-COVID levels, pushing fares higher again. "Fares have peaked in December of last year and they have been trending down since."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Fares trending down', argues Qantas boss

children.content: The head of Qantas says he "understands" criticism of the airline's large profit, at a time many are struggling with the cost of living.
Fronting a Senate inquiry, Alan Joyce has used his opening statement to argue that airlines are facing "a raft of escalating costs".
"When borders finally opened, the return to flying was not nearly as smooth as we had hoped," he said of the post-COVID chaos facing many travellers.
"Sick leave, supply chain issues and aircraft still in hibernation meant the industry could not meet the huge demand for travel.
"The result was long queues, delays and cancellations, particularly in domestic services, and for our part we apologise sincerely."
Mr Joyce also said airfares had peaked and were now trending down.
"To fix it quickly we had to cut capacity to reduce pressure on the system. This created an imbalance between supply and demand, which meant fares rose across all airlines.
"At the same time, fuel prices spiked by more than 60 per cent compared to pre-COVID levels, pushing fares higher again.
"Fares have peaked in December of last year and they have been trending down since."

image.altText: Aerial view of rows of new houses in outer suburbia.

items.synopsis: With the RBA due to meet next week, a growing number of Australians are defaulting on their home loans as those borrowers at risk of mortgage stress peak at levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

title.children: 'A perfect storm': New figures reveal extent of mortgage stress ahead of interest rates decision

image.altText: A young man in a military uniform wearing medals stands with his Navy cap under his arm.

items.synopsis: A mother tells the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide her son was "in hospital dying" when he was medically discharged from the Navy against his will.

title.children: David Finney once appeared in an ad for the Navy. Two years after being medically discharged, he took his own life

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

title.children: There's been an uproar after Spain's football boss kissed a player. Here's what's been said

title.children: Laura Kane's appointment as new football boss by AFL seen as groundbreaking moment in Australian sport

image.altText: Daniel Andrews wears a blue suit and white shirt and frowns while looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Victoria's cancellation of the 2026 regional Commonwealth Games is under scrutiny today, as a Senate inquiry holds hearings in Melbourne. Look back at how the day's hearing unfolded.

title.children: No attempt made to change Victoria's mind after 'emphatic' cancellation, Commonwealth Games inquiry hears — as it happened

image.altText: man wearing high-vis work shirt and base ball cap, looking away from the camera with glassy eyes

items.synopsis: Eighteen months on from last year's catastrophe, flood-affected northern NSW residents caught in limbo by the home buyback scheme call on the state government to fulfil its promises.

title.children: Craig is paying the mortgage on a flood-ravaged home he can't live in — and he doesn't qualify for a buyback

image.altText: A composite image showing a jubilant Zelenskyy on election night and the same man somber in 2023.

items.synopsis: When Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelenskyy was elected president by a landslide he said he would only stand for a single term. During peacetime, the next election would be just months away.

title.children: Millions of Ukrainians have fled and martial law is in effect. Is a 2024 election possible?

image.altText: A man in a dark suit leans over a map

items.synopsis: Over the last week focus on the war has been diverted by the plane crash in Russia which is believed to have killed the leader of the Wagner mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin, but there are bigger questions, writes John Lyons.

title.children: There are five possible ways the Ukraine war can end

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann object to Network Ten's bid to use a psychologist report into the behaviour of sexual assault victims in response to his defamation case.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyers object to Network Ten's bid to use psychologist report as part of defamation case

image.altText: The modern-looking facade of a building bearing the lettering "Forensic Medicine and Coroners Complex".

items.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a 15-year-old Indigenous boy who died in NSW in 2020 hears that each of the departments "thought another one was assisting".

title.children: 'Missed opportunities': Three agencies closed files on teen in lead-up to death, inquest hears

image.altText: A fire consumes a large timber structure.

items.synopsis: The Sydney to Brisbane rail line has been cut by a fire in a historic coal loader that lit up the night sky over a northern NSW town. See the video.

title.children: Rail history up in flames as coal loader destroyed in spectacular inferno

image.altText: Tokyo bedroom

items.synopsis: We challenged four reporters to find somewhere to live for 30 per cent of the average wage in their global cities. From "dorms for adults" to buildings that could be demolished at any moment, they saw it all.

title.children: What does 30pc of average household wage get you on the global rental market?

image.altText: A middle-aged man in dark suit speaks at podium in front of Australian and US flags

items.synopsis: Three of the 20 marines who survived a fatal military aircraft crash on Melville Island north of Darwin remain in hospital, as the recovery of the three marines killed in the crash continues.

title.children: Three US marines remain in hospital as recovery efforts from deadly crash continue

image.altText: Four people are silhouetted against the backdrop of the moon, which looks massive thanks to a special camera lens

items.synopsis: This week's will be the second full moon we've seen this month. It's going to appear a bit bigger and brighter — but it won't look blue.

title.children: The month will end with a rare supermoon. Here's the best night to see it

image.altText: A man in a black shirt sits beside water while a woman in a blue shirt puts her arms around his neck.

title.children: 'If I die, people outside won't know the truth': Australian fears death in Chinese prison after diagnosis

image.altText: Mother holding the wrist of a baby who is out of focus.

title.children: Patterson, Olyslagers in the high jump medals as Australia enjoys best-ever world champs haul
